column13: Fully developed autonomous production system at Cadia, including support functions capable of 24/7 production across a panel cave. Reduces hazard exposure rates of manual operators on the production level with application to other sites.
column20: Autonomous Production System, Panel Cave, Hazard Exposure Rates

column13: Ore sorting trials at Brucejack commenced following impressive positive preliminary results. Concept study now complete and detailed design on a trial installation and procurement of long-lead items well advanced. Selective oxidation at Lihir is currently being used, allowing for higher sulphur ore feeds, enabling bottleneck rates, lower energy transition in kWh/t and lower unit costs.
column20: Ore Sorting, BruceJack, Lower Unit Costs

column13: Three graduates are advancing the way we work underground at Cadia. Taking on the challenge to remove personnel from significant hazards, Aaron Gilbert, Logan Torrance and Finn Wedge created a robotic inspection platform custom-made for the fully autonomous PC1 extraction level. Together with help from graduate mentor and Senior Project Engineer Tom Corbett and Technology and Innovation Manager Jason Nitz, the trio built the SmartHog fromÃÂ scratch, from the design and construction of the mechanical and electrical systems to writing the computer code and implementing customised radar technology adapted from the automotive industry to control the machine and manage the outputs it produces.
column20: Three Graduates, Major Hazards, Graduate Mentor, and Senior Project Engineer

column6: Proportion of spending on local suppliers
column7: The total in the country of Goods and Supplies purchased locally consisted of near mine/local government area, state/province, and land was 65%. Meanwhile, the total services purchased locally consisted of near mine/local government area, state/province, and country 84%.

column6: Operations assessed for risks related to corruption
column7: Ten out of 10 (100%) of operations were assessed for organisational risks related to corruption during the reporting period. The following operations were set in FY23: Americas, Brucejack, Cadia, Exploration, Namosi/Fiji, Havieron, Lihir, Port Moresby, Red Chris, Telfer and Wafi-Golpu. \n\nIn line with Ethics & Compliance's assurance program, which includes the biannual E&C Review Sessions, each operation's E&C risks (e.g. conflicts of interest, bribery and corruption, training compliance, E&C compliance risks and controls, monitoring and review activities, issues management, and gifts, hospitality and sponsored travel) were reviewed with the assistance of each operation's E&C Champion(s). Whilst compliance controls were noted to require further strengthening in a few operations' key E&C risk areas, these were known and were being addressed. During the FY23 review period, no significant or material corruption issues were identified in our operations.

column6: Communication and training about anti-corruption policies and procedures
column13: In FY23, we developed new Ethics and compliance courses to be rolled out and completed by high-risk roles across the business in FY24 about our Code of Conduct, Anti-Bribery and corruption, Fraud, Conflicts of Interest, Privacy, and our Speak Out program. This Newcrest-centric training provides advice relevant to our jurisdictions, includes Ã¢ÂÂstop, think and askÃ¢ÂÂ moments, knowledge checks and activities based on investigation lessons, and builds on previously implemented training.
column20: High-Risk Roles, Anti-Bribery & Corruption, Fraud, Conflict of interest\t

column6: Confirmed incidents of corruption and actions taken
column7: In Cadia, there is a partially substantiated - Conflict of Interest whereby a contract provider allegedly assigns accommodation, and individuals within the company benefit financially from these arrangements. In Lihir, 1. Substantiated - 18 persons identified with fraudulent Electrical Licences and persons still on-site at the time of the findings were removed, with a permanent ban on their profile. 2. Substantiated - The contractor intentionally gave non-company personnel their boarding pass under their identity in an attempt to board a flight. 3. Substantiated - The contractor fraudulently obtained a Police Clearance Certificate through a 3rd party in Port Moresby.ÃÂ In Red Chris, Substantiated - an ex-employee used a Newcrest flight booking for personal use that had not been cancelled after the employee left the company.

Interactions with water as a shared resource
column7: Respecting the environment is a critical pillar in our sustainability approach. NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs Environmental Policy is supported by several performance standards that guide NewcrestÃ¢ÂÂs risk-based approach to management of water stewardship, land use and disturbance, biodiversity, waste rock and tailings management, hazardous waste and closure planning.

column8: Minerals Council of Australia (MCA) Water Accounting
column13: We use the Minerals Council of Australia (MCA) Water Accounting Framework to support water reporting for all our operations, complemented by the International Council on Mining and MetalsÃÂ (ICMM) Water Reporting Guidelines. Water extraction volumes, discharge volumes and quality are monitored by regulatory and internal requirements to mitigate potential impacts and manage risks.
column20: Minerals Council of Australia (MCA), Water Accounting, International Council on Mining and Metals (ICMM), Potential Impacts

column13: Newcrest has developed a water stewardship policy and water stewardship maturity framework to promote a catchment-based approach to the management of water aspects within the specific community and watershed context of each site. We use: Ã¢ÂÂ water in process plants for gold and copper production Ã¢ÂÂ seawater at Lihir for cooling and tailings dilution Ã¢ÂÂ dewatering for access to mine voids Ã¢ÂÂ water for dust suppression Ã¢ÂÂ water for services in camps, and potable water supplies.
column20: Water Stewardship Maturity Framework, Gold and Copper Production, Lihir

column13: Telfer, Red Chris and Cadia use terrestrial Tailings Storage Facilities (TSFs), while Lihir uses Deep-Sea Tailings Placement (DSTP) in a suitable deep-ocean location. DSTP was also selected as the preferred tailings management option for our Wafi-Golpu project. Brucejack conducts backfilling of tailings underground, complemented by controlled lake deposition under government approvals.
column20: Telfer, Red Chris, and Cadia, Tailings Storage Facilities, Wafi-Golpu Project
